awd_titl_txt: IRES: Advancing Cyber-Enabled, Decentralized Water Systems in Rapidly Developing Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses an enormous global challenge, the management and improvement of decentralized water systems, including treatment and delivery of fresh water as well as removal and treatment of wastewater. The project will provide an in-depth research and training opportunity for twelve graduate students in decentralized water systems in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. 

Outside of the United States, most urban water systems are decentralized, meaning they are built after housing is established. In many locations, these systems serve only a segment of an urban area. This project will provide US students a clear understanding of the specific challenges of decentralized water systems through hands-on experiences. Students will develop sensor systems, connected through cellular networks, to form data acquisition networks that can significantly improve the understanding and operation of decentralized water systems. 

The U.S. students and faculty team will work with five mentors from Addis Ababa University (AAU) who bring significant expertise in context-appropriate, decentralized water infrastructure and expertise. The U.S. students will be paired directly with AAU graduate students, using a peer-to-peer learning model likely to increase the technical impact and cultural exchange impacts of the project. Addis Ababa is excellent site for the proposed research. It is rapidly growing, with a strong existing decentralized water system and strong cellular networks to support the cyber-systems research. In addition, the city has need for more efficiency and further development of the water infrastructure. 

Strong dissemination efforts are planned that should increase the impact of this project beyond the cohort of participating students. The international team is developing a course on decentralized water systems that will address a significant lack of educational materials on decentralized water systems. In addition, each US student will submit abstracts to a national conference and an on-campus research symposia, and the team proposes to publish on the peer-to-peer learning model as well as papers on the specific research projects.

por.por_cntn:
Cities in the Global North have traditionally installed its water infrastructure concurrent with development.  This infrastructure is centralized, meaning that drinking water is treated at one location before distributing out to multiple users, or sewage and other wastewater is collected from all users and piped to a single treatment location.  In contrast, rapidly growing cities in developing countries of the Global South are growing with new buildings and roads but water infrastructure is not fully built out as has been done with centralized water infrastructure.  Instead, urban water infrastructure in the Global South is largely decentralized, meaning that collection and treatment is done locally at the neighborhood or building scale.  Students in the U.S., therefore, rarely have experience with decentralized water infrastructure, despite the fact that it serves the vast majority of the world’s population currently. 

This project is focused on advancing research efforts around decentralized urban water systems. Because of the University of Michigan’s (U-M’s) strong connections with Addis Ababa University (AAU) in Ethiopia, we partnered with them to provide opportunities for collaborative (student-to-student) research experiences around decentralized water infrastructure and planning using data-rich or sensor-based methods.  Therefore, the goal of our project was to: (1) expose U.S. graduate student participants to decentralized water infrastructure within Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, among the most rapidly growing cities in Africa; (2) partner U.S. students with Ethiopian college students who are completing projects on these systems; (3) design and assess the operation of sensor-mediated or data-rich decentralized units; and (4) evaluate what would be necessary to integrate these decentralized water infrastructure elements as a system. Over the project period, the U-M and AAU teams deployed and demonstrated multiple water infrastructure components that included sensors or data-rich analysis, and demonstrated that sensor-based data could be collected via cell network in Addis Ababa, sent to the cloud, and received by University of Michigan collaborators.

During the 2018 summer, we implemented a shortened trip to evaluate what was possible using Ethiopia’s government-managed cellular network as a medium for collecting and transmitting data from a sensor to the cloud.  We also identified data sources for water infrastructure, and met potential partners.  Then, in 2019, we invited our first full cohort of students who spent at least eight weeks in Addis Ababa partnered with Ethiopian student counterparts implementing five different decentralized or green infrastructure water-related projects.  The students gave a culminating seminar at AAU. In preparation for the travel in both 2018 and 2019, a new project-based course was developed and offered by co-PIs Love and Larsen for those traveling as well as other interested students.  Students had an opportunity during the course to identify possible projects that were offered and vetted by AAU faculty collaborators, design a testbed deployment, and purchase parts and supplies prior to traveling. 

Consequences from the global SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and civil unrest in Ethiopia prevented travel and the preparative project-based course from being offered in 2020 through 2023.  Because our project reached the end of the period when funds could be expended, unused funds were returned and the project was ended.
